did.unittitle: Ted Gilien photographs of postwar Japan and the Philippines
did.abstract: This collection contains approximately 500 photographs taken by combat artist and painter Ted Gilien ca. 1945-1946 documenting war destruction in Japan and the Philippines. He later used many of the photographs as source materials for his paintings.

chronitem.event: Ted Gilien born in Brooklyn, New York
Attended the Art Students League and the National Academy of Art in New York City
Participated in the Federal Arts Project as a mural and easel painter
Painted a post office mural in Lees Summit, Missouri
Employed as a shipyard worker in San Pedro, California
Served as a combat artist with the US military and covered areas of Japan decimated by atomic bombs as well as the Philippines
Displayed artwork at 20 one-man shows on the West Coast
Published the Price, a collection of 50 anti-war paintings and drawings
Held show in New York at Associated American Artists
Published a Visual History of the Maccabees, comprised of 180 paintings and drawings
Exhibited at over 500 shows, represented in more than 400 private and public collections, and received 26 major awards
Taught at Chouinard, Kann, Palos Verdes, Westside Jewish, Pasadena Community Center, and the University of Judaism
Exhibited one man shows at the International Design Center in LA, the LA Sports Arena, the Inheritance Gallery, and the Renaissance Gallery in Beverly Hills
Awarded first prize at the California State Fair

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The collection contains approximately 500 black and white photographs taken ca. 1945-1946 in Japan and the Philippines. The photographs document the destruction caused by the atomic bomb in Nagasaki including the ruins of the Urakami Cathedral. Along with significant photographs depicting building destruction, many images depict Japanese citizens clearing rubble, living in the streets in makeshift camps, or moving bundled belongings by any means available. The photographs also include images of ruined Japanese boats, ships, and military planes. A few photographs depict crowds at the Imperial Palace in Tokyo as well as kabuki theatre. The collection also contains photographs of US GIs serving in Japan. Photographs from the Philippines focus on images of citizens living in rough and meager conditions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p:
The collection is arranged into the following series:

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: St. Mary's Cathedral, also called Urakami Cathedral due to its location in Urakami in the northern region of the city of Nagasaki, was originally constructed in 1895. The brick Romanesque Catholic Church was destroyed when an atomic bomb was dropped on Nagasaki on August 9, 1945 and a replacement building was constructed in 1959.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This file contains images of wrecked Japanese military planes, some photographs taken during flight, and images of wrecked military and civilian boats and vessels.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The file contains images of vehicles, bicycles, and carts used to move bundled belongings along with images of citizens living in makeshift camps amidst war destruction. The file also contains some images of intact buildings and monuments.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The file contains images of Japanese men and soldiers clearing rubble.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The file contains images of men and crowds in the streets or living in makeshift camps. Some images depict possible delousing.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Kabuki is a traditional Japanese dance-drama known for the stylization of its drama and the elaborate makeup worn by its performers.
